facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 10, 1953 of Calcutta High Court Original Side in I.T. Reference No. 8 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 10, 1953, of the Calcutta High Court  Original Side  in I. T. Reference No. 8 of 1947.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 24, 1957 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. April 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-

facts.text: Respondent is a company carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business,

facts.text: Dispute relates to excess profits tax assessment on income from business other than life insurance for chargeable accounting periods ending December 31, 1940 and December 31, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: and the present dispute relates to the assessment of excess profits tax on its income from business other than life insurance for the chargeable accounting periods ending December 31, 1940, and December 31, 1941.

facts.text: Insurance policies other than life issued for short periods or ad hoc for specified voyage or event.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate the companytentions raised, it is necessary to state that the policies of insurance with which these proceedings are companycerned, are, unlike life insurance policies, issued in general for short periods or ad hoc

facts.text: Fire insurance policies normally issued for one year, whole premium received when issued.

anchor.surface_text: To take the most important of them, fire insurance policies, they are issued numbermally for one year, and the whole of the premium due thereon is received when the policies are actually issued.

facts.text: In given year, premiums received in full but risks run only in part, part outstanding for next year.

anchor.surface_text: In any given year, while the premiums due on the policies would have been received in full, the risks companyered by them would have run only in part and a, part will be outstanding for the next year.

facts.text: Respondent prepares annual profit and loss statements and revenue statements under Insurance Act, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The companypanies have to prepare annual statements of profit and loss for the purpose of ascertaining their profits and distributing their dividends. They have also to prepare revenue statements to be sent to the authorities under the provisions of the Insurance Act, 1938.

facts.text: Respondent's method: premiums received included in assets, 40% treated as reserve for unexpired risks shown as liability.

anchor.surface_text: The method 1004 adopted by the respondent in preparing the above statements has been that while the premiums received are all of them included in the assets of the year, a certain proportion thereof, usually 40 per cent., is treated as the reserve for unexpired risks,

facts.text: Example: In 1939, respondent issued fire policies, received Rs. 1,00,000 premiums, shown as income, Rs. 40,000 as reserve for unexpired risks.

anchor.surface_text: To take a companycrete example, if in the year 1939 the respondent issued annual fire insurance policies and received a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 as premiums thereof, the whole of it would be shown as income in the statement for the year 1939, and a sum of Rs. 40,000 will be shown as a reserve for unexpired risks.

facts.text: In profit and loss statement, premiums as assets, reserve as liability, balance in net profits.

anchor.surface_text: In the profit and loss statement, the former will be shown as part of the assets and the latter as liability, and it is only the balance that will be included in the net profits.

facts.text: In 1940, 1939 policies expired, Rs. 40,000 reserve treated as asset in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: In 1940, the policies issued in 1939 would all of them have expired, and the sum of Rs. 40,000 shown as reserve in 1939 would be treated as -part of the assets in 1940.

facts.text: Method of accounting adopted by insurance companies in accordance with recognised practice.

anchor.surface_text: This method of account- keeping is what is usually adopted by insurance companypanies, and is in accordance with well-recognised and approved practice of accountancy.

facts.text: Appellant contends reserves for unexpired risks deductible under r. 2 Sch. II as outstanding liability.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant is that if all the premiums received are to be treated as capital under r. 1, Sch. 11, then the sums which represent the outstanding liability in respect of the unexpired period of the policies-in the illustration given above, Rs. 40,000-should be deducted as a liability under r. 2 of Sch. II.

facts.text: Respondent claims provision for unexpired risks is contingent liability not within r. 2 Sch. II.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, while claiming that all the premiums received mu-,it be treated as capital, maintains that the provision for unexpired risks is- a companytingent liability, and that that 1005 is number within r. 2 of Sch. II.

facts.text: Tribunal decided question against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal decided the question against the respondent,

facts.text: Calcutta High Court on reference under s.66(1) Indian Income-tax Act read with s.21 Excess Profits Tax Act answered adversely to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: but on reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act read with s. 21 of the Act, the High Court of Calcutta answered the question adversely to the appellant,

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under s.66A leading to this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: but granted a certificate under s. 66-A, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Statements furnished to Controller of Insurance disclosed 40% of premiums as reserve for unexpired risks, treated as liability, allowed in income-tax assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the statements furnished to the Controller of Insurance by the respondent for the relevant periods did disclose 40 per cent. of the premiums received as reserve for unexpired risks on the outstanding policies and that the same has been treated as a liability in its profits and loss statements and allowed in the assessment of income-tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds reserve for unexpired risks not an accruing liability under r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be held to be an is accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. 11 to the Act.
r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act XV of 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises a question of importance as to whether amounts shown by an insurance companypany as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act XV of 1940

arguments.claim: Reserves for unexpired risks should be deducted as outstanding liability under r. 2 Sch. II if premiums treated as capital under r. 1 Sch. II

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant is that if all the premiums received are to be treated as capital under r. 1, Sch. 11, then the sums which represent the outstanding liability in respect of the unexpired period of the policies-in the illustration given above, Rs. 40,000-should be deducted as a liability under r. 2 of Sch. II.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reserve is contingent, not accruing liability like borrowed money or debts; does not contribute to earning profits as effective trading asset.

arguments.claim: Provision for unexpired risks is a contingent liability not within r. 2 Sch. II

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, while claiming that all the premiums received mu-,it be treated as capital, maintains that the provision for unexpired risks is- a contingent liability, and that that 1005 is number within r. 2 of Sch. II.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; contingent liability does not affect capital position for earning profits under EPTA.

arguments.claim: Contract of insurance complete on policy issuance; risk attaches creating accruing liability under r. 2 sufficient even if not accrued

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned Solicitor General is that it must be so regarded, and his argument in support of it may thus be stated A contract of insurance is complete as soon as the policy is issued. From that time, the risk begins to attach to it, and there is a liability incurred.

arguments.court_reasoning: Liability must be of character like borrowed money/debts, effective for business profits; insurance reserve is contingent.

arguments.claim: Reserve shown by assessee is sum in respect of accruing liability deductible under r. 2

anchor.surface_text: Liability under a policy must be held to be accruing so long as the policy is in force, because it can ripen into actual liability at any time during the life of the policy on the happening -of the specified event.

arguments.claim: EPTA schemes differ from IT Act; IT allowance not conclusive for EPT capital

anchor.surface_text: on the footing that r. 6 in the Schedule to the Indian Income-tax Act has adopted the law as laid down in Sun Insurance Office v. Clark, the question still remains whether unexpired risk in an

arguments.claim: Object of EPTA is to tax profits above standard level varying with capital employed; factual basis for capital

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Excess Profits Tax Act is to tax profits of a business when they overflow a certain level. That level is determined thus A certain,period called the standard period is taken the capital invested and the profits made in the business during that year are ascertained,

arguments.claim: r.1 Sch.II includes all assets utilised in business on factual basis; r.2 deducts borrowed money/debts to limit relief to own capital

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1 of Sch. II to the Act enumerates three categories of properties, which are to be included in the computation of capital. It is to be noted that this rule does not adopt any legalistic or conventional notion of what is technically termed capital but it proceeds on a factual basis

arguments.claim: Accruing liabilities under r.2 must be same character as borrowed money/debts per noscitur a sociis; effective profit-earning trading assets

anchor.surface_text: of the same character as borrowed money and debts with which they are associated on the principle of noscitur a sociis. They must be such as can be said to have been utilised in the business and formed part of the really effective trading assets

arguments.claim: Deduction under IT s.10 differs from r.2 Sch.II EPTA; former reduces profits, latter reduces capital increasing tax

anchor.surface_text: It should not be overlooked that a deduction under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and that under r. 2 of Sch. 11 to the Act proceed on totally different lines and have different objects in view.

arguments.claim: Sun Insurance principle inappropriate for EPT capital as treats reserve as unearned income not capital

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, how inappropriate the principle laid down in Sun Insurance Office v. Clark 1 would be if it is applied for determining the question of capital employed in business for the purpose of Excess Profits Tax Act

arguments.claim: Reserve for unexpired risks not real trading asset contributing to profits; something in the air

anchor.surface_text: The reserve liability could not factually be said to have contributed to the running of the business or the earning of profits. It was something in the air, and could have had no effect in the working of the concern,

arguments.claim: Northern Aluminium supports: contingent liability not accruing even if allowed in IT; no effect on capital position

anchor.surface_text: A case very much in point is the decision in Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 1 . There, the question arose whether a conditional liability under a contract was an accruing liability within the corresponding provision in the English Excess Profits Tax Act.

holdings.text: amounts shown by an insurance company as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are not liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act XV of 1940

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises a question of importance as to whether amounts shown by an insurance companypany as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act XV of 1940

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reserve for unexpired risks is a contingent liability, not an accruing liability of the character of borrowed money or debts; it is not a real effective trading asset contributing to earning profits.

holdings.text: the sum of Rs. 40,000 which is set apart in 1939 as reserve for unexpired risks is not liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act from out of the capital employed in business for that year

anchor.surface_text: The whole controversy between the parties relates to the other condition whether the reserve of 40 per cent. can be regarded as a sum in respect of accruing liability. The contention of the learned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reserve represents contingent obligation under insurance policy, not accruing like debts; distinguished from IT computation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sun Insurance applies to IT profits under s.10 but EPTA capital computation under Sch.II differs fundamentally in purpose and scheme.

holdings.text: the reserve for unexpired risks is not an accruing liability within r. 2

anchor.surface_text: In this view, is the reserve for unexpired risks an accruing liability within r. -2 ? The decision in. Sun Insurance Office v. Clark that it should be allowed as a deduction was based

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sun Insurance grounds (unearned income, unpaid purchase price analogy) inapplicable to EPT capital; reserve not real trading asset.

holdings.text: accruing liabilities under r.2 Sch.II must be of the same character as borrowed money and debts per noscitur a sociis; effective trading assets utilised in business contributing to profits

anchor.surface_text: of the same character as borrowed money and debts with which they are associated on the principle of noscitur a sociis. They must be such as can be said to have been utilised in the business and formed part

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of rr.1-2 Sch.II EPTA requires factual profit-earning assets; borrowed money/debts reduce own capital relief.

holdings.text: principles in Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners applicable; contingent liability in respect of unexpired risk is not an accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the principles laid down in Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 1 and Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. 2 are applicable to the decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contingent liability does not affect capital position for earning profits under EPTA, even if allowed in IT assessment.

holdings.text: deduction under s.10 Income-tax Act and under r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act proceed on totally different lines and have different objects

anchor.surface_text: It should not be overlooked that a deduction under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and that under r. 2 of Sch. 11 to the Act proceed on totally different lines and have different objects in view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: IT reduces taxable profits (assessee benefit); EPT reduces capital (revenue claim, increases tax liability).

holdings.text: sums in respect of reserve for unexpired risks allowable as deduction in computing profits for excess profits tax

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the statements furnished to the Controller of Insurance by the respondent for the relevant periods did disclose 40 per cent. of the premiums received as reserve for unexpired risks

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground based on r.1 Sch.I EPTA adopting IT s.10(7) and Sch rule 6; allowed in IT assessment.

precedents.cited_proposition: Amounts reserved for unexpired risks should be deducted in computing profits as they represent unearned premium or liability analogous to unpaid purchase price
precedents.cited_holding: the amounts reserved for unexpired risks should be deducted firstly on the ground that the premium which had been paid in respect of a risk for a whole year could not be said to have been wholly earned

anchor.surface_text: Webb v. Stenton 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Definition of debt as a sum of money presently payable or to become payable in future by reason of present obligation (debitum in praesenti, solvendum in futuro)
precedents.cited_holding: a debt legal or equitable can be attached whether it be a debt owing or accruing but it must be debt, and a debt is a sum of money which is now payable or will become payable
